channel.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
channel.description:
Alright, so I was under the assumption for quite some time now that a software engineer was just a fancy name for somebody who develops programs, but after further research I have discovered that this is not exactly the case. At [url=http://work.chron.com/differences-between-software-engineer-computer-programmer-7587.html]this[/url] link, it says
Software engineers, often called software developers, plan and create programs. They analyze user needs, design software and then test it to ensure quality. They give instructions to programmers who write the software codes. Engineers who specialize in the operating systems needed by computers are called systems software developers. Those who focus on applications, such as games, video editors, word processors and databases, are called applications software developers. They require a minimum bachelor’s degree in software engineering, computer science or a related field. Though they do not usually write code, they also need strong programming skills to communicate properly with programmers.
Which doesn't sound accurate in any way, obviously not written by somebody of either trade, then this [url=https://answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20071020191123AA0UHz8]Yahoo Answers[/url] link goes on to try to further explain the difference, but I'm afraid I still can't make much sense out of it. From what sense I can make out of what I've read, it seems like software engineers are either (a) The persons who develop the virtual machines and programming frameworks and what not, i.e. .NET and Java itself, or (b) The persons who mainly deal in developing base API's for companies so that developers can utilize them for their tasks. Anybody care to shed light on this for me?

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

There’s a story behind software engineering. Software development as a profession has an awful reputation. Statistically speaking most projects fail - they go over budget, they run over deadlines, or the software isn’t fit for purpose.
The idea with software engineering is that it’s supposed to add engineering rigour to the software development process, thereby mitigating these failures.

Has it worked though? Not really.

Read full topic
item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused

Software engineering, as in the degree, tends to be attract many who suffer from aspergers
[/quote]
It’s astounding how true this statement is LOL[/quote]
Exactly, it was less shock humor and more so the truth.

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Software engineering, as in the degree, tends to be attract many who suffer from aspergers. Job titles for people who develop tend to be software engineer or developer. The beauty of computer science is that you can be hired as the aforementioned or do research.

item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:22, topic:547066”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=665967.msg4452635#msg4452635 date=1412605628]

It’s not even a proper engineering field lelelelelelelel

[me=Yz85Racer]smirks and returns to his top of the food chain in the engineering sciences[/me]

Yeah I kinda figured that one out lol…

TIL that there’s literally [me] tags on here, I always thought people went through the trouble of changing the text to red…

hint: type / me without the space

are you interested in doing the “manual work” of a software development team, someone who actually writes the code? Or being in more of a leading role where you may write some code, but more than likely most of your responsibilities will be to oversee the programmers, and deal with the high end spectrum of a project?

That’s hard for me to say, I’d imagine that I’d have to do the “manual work” to get the experience before I would get hired to lead a team…
[/quote]
Not necessarily… consider the difference between an electrical engineer and an electrician. You don’t work up from being an electrician to lead an electrical project… the engineer is trained as the engineer (obviously) and the electrician is more “hands on” practical side of it[/quote]
True. I guess I would rather take more of a leadership position by setting a overall design to work from while overseeing the project…

Read full topic
item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Yz85Racer: By that you’re probably referring to either a project leader or a systems architect. Not that it really matters, though, as a project leader of one project may very well be able to take the role as a systems developer of another project. In other cases there’s no difference at all, and everyone can take the role as anything. That’s usually the case if the company doesn’t have that many employees, like smaller companies.

I have worked for six companies so far. One of them with around 800 employees, whereas the others were pretty small ones. As of yet, only one of those companies had a systems architect (not the large company). We also used Scrum there, so he was also the Scrum Master. On the company where I work now, we have a project leader whom barely write any code for the project that he leads. Although he is a systems developer in other projects, so he does write more code than that.

Read full topic
item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused

item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Snow_:

Software Engineers are the guys who meet with the clients and create UML text and/or diagrams bases on what the client wants. The developers (programmers) then do the actual programming. This is basicly reading the UML and writing it in a programming language.

Not sure this is entirely true, or at least this isn’t their full job.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_engineering
Yes, it’s not the best source.

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

For me a degree never really made any difference. If you’ve done a lot of projects, that’s much better. Even better if you’re into open source.

On my CV I have more than ten projects listed. You don’t even have to add a lot of information about each project. The reason is that the people recruiting oftentimes don’t even understand what you’re writing. They believe you based on your “advanced” descriptions. Maybe you’ve used a “buzz” word that they’ve heard before.

Read full topic

[quote=“object, post:5, topic:547066”]The Project Leader usually do not write a lot of code, if any. That’s also the case in my current project at my job. However, I’m the lead Systems Developer (but I like to call myself the Systems Architect, even though that’s not really what I am).

So what I really do, is take care of the main design and architecture (including design patterns, yes) of our project. A project that consists of our own hardware and software and costs a few million dollars. :)[/quote]
Nice lol, so I’m guessing that many degrees (Software Engineering, Computer Programming, Computer Science, etc.) all lead to the same job areas.

So what I really do, is take care of the main design and architecture (including design patterns, yes) of our project. A project that consists of our own hardware and software and costs a few million dollars.

item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

So basically if I was to be considered a “Software Engineer” and I was working one a project with a team of “Computer Programmers”, I would be the one almost “leading” in a way, I’d be the one coming up with design patterns and such, creating a skeleton for everyone to follow?

Read full topic
item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused

item.title: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

That sounds fairly accurate. obv usage varies depending on who you talk to, and what bullshit titles organisations come up with for their devs… but this is my general interpretation:

Programmer - someone who writes code, whether it be assembly or javascript. may or may not get involved with high level design.

Software engineer - a programmer who follows standard software engineering methodologies, uses good design patterns etc.

so a software engineer could write system code (bash scripts, C, etc), they could build applications, APIs, etc, doesn’t really matter imo

Read full topic
item.source: Software Engineer vs. Computer Programmer, I'm Confused
